question: Will an Ivy League team make it to the Sweet Sixteen of the 2025 NCAA men's tournament ("March Madness")?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered evidence, here is the analysis regarding the probability of an Ivy League team making it to the Sweet Sixteen of the 2025 NCAA men's tournament:

1. **Yale's Performance and Potential Upset**: Yale won the Ivy League tournament and secured a berth in the NCAA tournament. They are predicted by the SportsLine model to potentially upset No. 4 Texas A&M in the first round. Yale has only lost once in 2025 and is led by a strong player, John Poulakidas, who averaged 19.2 points per game.

2. **Competitive Landscape**: Despite Yale's strong performance, the overall competitive landscape of the tournament is challenging. The Bleacher Report predictions did not mention any Ivy League teams in the Sweet Sixteen, focusing instead on stronger teams like Auburn, Michigan State, and UConn.

3. **Historical Context**: Historically, Ivy League teams have been underdogs in the NCAA tournament. While upsets are possible, they are not common for Ivy League teams to advance to the Sweet Sixteen.

4. **Predictions and Simulations**: The CBS Sports simulation predicts a potential upset by Yale in the first round, but there is no strong indication that they will advance to the Sweet Sixteen. The model's track record of predicting upsets gives some hope, but it remains a difficult path.

Considering these factors, while there is a possibility for an Ivy League team like Yale to make a surprising run, the probability remains low given the competition and historical performance.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.15

PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- [John Poulakidas](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898238/john-poulakidas) knocked down five 3-pointers in the second half as regular-season champion Yale added the Ivy League tournament championship with a 90-84 win over Cornell on Sunday to earn a berth in the NCAA tournament for the fourth time in the last five seasons.

The senior guard got off to a slow start, scoring just two points in the first half and missing all four 3-point attempts as Yale took a 37-32 advantage into intermission. That changed to start the second half when he erupted for eight points during a 90-second span, burying two 3s and a jumper to push the Bulldogs' lead to 16 points, 50-34 with under 16 minutes to play.

Cornell clawed back. [Guy Ragland Jr](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898218/guy-ragland-jr)., [Adam Hinton](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5106243/adam-hinton) and [Nazir Williams](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898217/nazir-williams) each hit 3-pointers in the span of just over a minute to get within seven and Ragland hit two more 3s to make it 60-58 with 9:18 left. [Bez Mbeng](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898237/bez-mbeng) answered with a 3 for Yale and Poulakidas hit from deep to make it 66-60, but Cornell got a three-point play from [AK Okereke](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5114350/ak-okereke) to make it a three-point game. [Trevor Mullin](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5177185/trevor-mullin) and Poulakidas each hit a 3 and [Nick Townsend](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5107174/nick-townsend) scored twice during a 10-4 run for a76-68 lead with five minutes left.

# NCAA Tournament 2025: Predictions for Men's Sweet 16 Bracket After Selection Sunday

It's been less than 24 hours since Selection Sunday, yet college basketball fans around the world are already working diligently to craft the perfect bracket.

Before the tournament officially gets under way on Thursday, bracket-makers will closely monitor this year's favorites, sleepers, and potential underdogs.

Since 2007-08, an 11-seed has made the Sweet 16 every year.

Meanwhile, UConn is attempting to win the tournament for the third consecutive year.

Can Dan Hurley's Huskies accomplish the rare feat despite likely facing No. 1 seed Florida in the Round of 32?

Below, I'll do my best to help you prepare, forecasting my Sweet 16 for this year's big dance.

*Click here to play the NCAA March Madness Men's Bracket Challenge.*

**Predictions for Sweet 16 Matchups**

Auburn vs. UC San Diego

Michigan State vs. Iowa State

Despite losing three of their final four games, Auburn still ended up as the top No. 1 seed in this year's big dance.

The Tigers have won an impressive 16 of 21 Quad 1 games and boast one of the nation's best offenses, led by Wooden Award Finalist Johni Broome.

Their recent struggles shouldn't overshadow how deep this program is, and making it to at least the Sweet 16 is expected—even with a potentially challenging Round of 32 matchup against Louisville or Creighton.

In the Sweet 16, it's quite likely the Tigers will face fourth-seeded Texas A&M or 12-seed UC San Diego, who I expect to upset Michigan in the opening round.

The Tritons have won 15 straight games and rank in the top 35 of the [NET Rankings](https://www.ncaa.com/rankings/basketball-men/d1/ncaa-mens-basketball-net-rankings), an impressive ranking for a mid-major program.

In the bottom of the draw, two-seed Michigan State could face difficulties with the winner of Marquette-New Mexico, but nonetheless should be able to advance given their dominant defense and top-tier record (13-5) in Quad 1 games this season.

The UC San Diego Tritons made the 2025 NCAA bracket in their first year eligible for the NCAA Tournament after transitioning from Division II. They went 30-4, winning both the Big West's regular season and conference tournament titles and enter the Big Dance as a No. 12 seed in the South Region. The Tritons rank 35th in the NCAA's NET Ranking metric, among the top non-power conference schools. Led by star guard Aniwaniwa Tait-Jones (19.5 points per game), UCSD will face off against Big Ten Tournament champion Michigan in the Round of 64 of March Madness 2025. Can the No. 12 Tritons pull the upset over the No. 5 seed Wolverines? Before you make your 2025 NCAA Tournament predictions, [see the March Madness bracket picks from the proven computer model at SportsLine](https://www.sportsline.com/insiders/2025-sportsline-upset-bracket-full-of-surprises/#ttag=03162025_agg_cbssports_picks_basketball_ncaa_model_MMupsetbracket1).

The model has beaten over 91 percent of all CBS Sports bracket players in four of the past six tournaments.

This model, which simulates every game 10,000 times, has nailed 24 first-round upsets by double-digit seeds since its inception in 2016 and nailed UConn's championship run last year. It nailed 13 teams in the Sweet 16 and was all over Alabama's Cinderella run to the Final Four as a 4-seed.

Now, SportsLine's advanced computer model has simulated the entire 2025 March Madness bracket 10,000 times to come up with the perfect 2025 NCAA Tournament bracket and find out which teams will pull off the biggest upsets. author: Associated Press
url: https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/44278450/yale-tops-cornell-win-ivy-title-claim-ncaa-tournament-berth

description: Regular-season champion Yale added the Ivy League Tournament title with a 90-84 win over Cornell on Sunday to earn a berth in the NCAA tournament.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- [John Poulakidas](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898238/john-poulakidas) knocked down five 3-pointers in the second half as regular-season champion Yale added the Ivy League tournament championship with a 90-84 win over Cornell on Sunday to earn a berth in the NCAA tournament for the fourth time in the last five seasons.

The senior guard got off to a slow start, scoring just two points in the first half and missing all four 3-point attempts as Yale took a 37-32 advantage into intermission. That changed to start the second half when he erupted for eight points during a 90-second span, burying two 3s and a jumper to push the Bulldogs' lead to 16 points, 50-34 with under 16 minutes to play.

Cornell clawed back. [Guy Ragland Jr](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898218/guy-ragland-jr)., [Adam Hinton](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5106243/adam-hinton) and [Nazir Williams](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898217/nazir-williams) each hit 3-pointers in the span of just over a minute to get within seven and Ragland hit two more 3s to make it 60-58 with 9:18 left. [Bez Mbeng](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898237/bez-mbeng) answered with a 3 for Yale and Poulakidas hit from deep to make it 66-60, but Cornell got a three-point play from [AK Okereke](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5114350/ak-okereke) to make it a three-point game. [Trevor Mullin](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5177185/trevor-mullin) and Poulakidas each hit a 3 and [Nick Townsend](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5107174/nick-townsend) scored twice during a 10-4 run for a76-68 lead with five minutes left.

Poulakidas finished 8 of 14 from the floor, including 5-for-9 from distance, while going 4-for-4 from the line. Townsend finished with 19 points with four assists and two steals, Mbeng contributed 15 points, seven rebounds and four assists and [Casey Si…

# NCAA Tournament 2025: Predictions for Men's Sweet 16 Bracket After Selection Sunday

It's been less than 24 hours since Selection Sunday, yet college basketball fans around the world are already working diligently to craft the perfect bracket.

Before the tournament officially gets under way on Thursday, bracket-makers will closely monitor this year's favorites, sleepers, and potential underdogs.

Since 2007-08, an 11-seed has made the Sweet 16 every year.

Meanwhile, UConn is attempting to win the tournament for the third consecutive year.

Can Dan Hurley's Huskies accomplish the rare feat despite likely facing No. 1 seed Florida in the Round of 32?

Below, I'll do my best to help you prepare, forecasting my Sweet 16 for this year's big dance.

*Click here to play the NCAA March Madness Men's Bracket Challenge.*

**Predictions for Sweet 16 Matchups**

Auburn vs. UC San Diego

Michigan State vs. Iowa State

Despite losing three of their final four games, Auburn still ended up as the top No. 1 seed in this year's big dance.

The Tigers have won an impressive 16 of 21 Quad 1 games and boast one of the nation's best offenses, led by Wooden Award Finalist Johni Broome.

Their recent struggles shouldn't overshadow how deep this program is, and making it to at least the Sweet 16 is expected—even with a potentially challenging Round of 32 matchup against Louisville or Creighton.

In the Sweet 16, it's quite likely the Tigers will face fourth-seeded Texas A&M or 12-seed UC San Diego, who I expect to upset Michigan in the opening round.

The Tritons have won 15 straight games and rank in the top 35 of the [NET Rankings](https://www.ncaa.com/rankings/basketball-men/d1/ncaa-mens-basketball-net-rankings), an impressive ranking for a mid-major program.

In the bottom of the draw, two-seed Michigan State could face difficulties with the winner of Marquette-New Mexico, but nonetheless should be able to advance given their dominant defense and top-tier record (13-5) in Quad 1 games this season.

In the Sweet 16, it would not be a surprise for the Spartans to face an Iowa State team that, despite being without senior guard Keshon Gilbert, is still exp…

author: CBS Sports Staff •

description: When does the March Madness 2025 schedule start, and when are 2025 NCAA Tournament brackets due? The 2025 March Madness bracket begins on Thursday, March 20
sitename: CBSSports.com

The UC San Diego Tritons made the 2025 NCAA bracket in their first year eligible for the NCAA Tournament after transitioning from Division II. They went 30-4, winning both the Big West's regular season and conference tournament titles and enter the Big Dance as a No. 12 seed in the South Region. The Tritons rank 35th in the NCAA's NET Ranking metric, among the top non-power conference schools. Led by star guard Aniwaniwa Tait-Jones (19.5 points per game), UCSD will face off against Big Ten Tournament champion Michigan in the Round of 64 of March Madness 2025. Can the No. 12 Tritons pull the upset over the No. 5 seed Wolverines? Before you make your 2025 NCAA Tournament predictions, [see the March Madness bracket picks from the proven computer model at SportsLine](https://www.sportsline.com/insiders/2025-sportsline-upset-bracket-full-of-surprises/#ttag=03162025_agg_cbssports_picks_basketball_ncaa_model_MMupsetbracket1).

Last year, SportsLine's computer simulation nailed massive upsets, including huge wins by No. 11 Oregon over No. 6 South Carolina, No. 11 NC State over No. 6 Texas Tech, No. 10 Colorado over No. 7 Florida, and No. 12 James Madison over No. 5 Wisconsin last year. The model has beaten over 91 percent of all CBS Sports bracket players in four of the past six tournaments.

This model, which simulates every game 10,000 times, has nailed 24 first-round upsets by double-digit seeds since its inception in 2016 and nailed UConn's championship run last year. It nailed 13 teams in the Sweet 16 and was all over Alabama's Cinderella run to the Final Four as a 4-seed.

Now, SportsLine's advanced computer model has simulated the entire 2025 March Madness bracket 10,000 times to come up with the perfect 2025 NCAA Tournament bracket and find out which teams will pull off the biggest upsets. You shouldn't even think about making a pick [without seeing what their model has to say](https://www.sportsline.com/insiders/2025-sports…

title: Yale beats Cornell to win Ivy title, tourney berth
author: Associated Press
url: https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/44278450/yale-tops-cornell-win-ivy-title-claim-ncaa-tournament-berth
hostname: espn.com
description: Regular-season champion Yale added the Ivy League Tournament title with a 90-84 win over Cornell on Sunday to earn a berth in the NCAA tournament.
sitename: ESPN
date: 2025-03-16
---
PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- [John Poulakidas](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898238/john-poulakidas) knocked down five 3-pointers in the second half as regular-season champion Yale added the Ivy League tournament championship with a 90-84 win over Cornell on Sunday to earn a berth in the NCAA tournament for the fourth time in the last five seasons.

The senior guard got off to a slow start, scoring just two points in the first half and missing all four 3-point attempts as Yale took a 37-32 advantage into intermission. That changed to start the second half when he erupted for eight points during a 90-second span, burying two 3s and a jumper to push the Bulldogs' lead to 16 points, 50-34 with under 16 minutes to play.

Cornell clawed back. [Guy Ragland Jr](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898218/guy-ragland-jr)., [Adam Hinton](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5106243/adam-hinton) and [Nazir Williams](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898217/nazir-williams) each hit 3-pointers in the span of just over a minute to get within seven and Ragland hit two more 3s to make it 60-58 with 9:18 left. [Bez Mbeng](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/4898237/bez-mbeng) answered with a 3 for Yale and Poulakidas hit from deep to make it 66-60, but Cornell got a three-point play from [AK Okereke](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5114350/ak-okereke) to make it a three-point game. [Trevor Mullin](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5177185/trevor-mullin) and Poulakidas each hit a 3 and [Nick Townsend](https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/player/_/id/5107174/nick-townsend) scored twice during a 10-4 run for a76-68 lead with five minutes left.

Poulakidas finished 8 of 14 from the floor, including 5-for-9 from distance, while going 4-for-4 from the line. Townsend finished with 19 points with four assists and two steals, Mbeng contributed 15 points, seven rebounds and four assists and [Casey Si…

# NCAA Tournament 2025: Predictions for Men's Sweet 16 Bracket After Selection Sunday

It's been less than 24 hours since Selection Sunday, yet college basketball fans around the world are already working diligently to craft the perfect bracket.

Before the tournament officially gets under way on Thursday, bracket-makers will closely monitor this year's favorites, sleepers, and potential underdogs.

Since 2007-08, an 11-seed has made the Sweet 16 every year.

Meanwhile, UConn is attempting to win the tournament for the third consecutive year.

Can Dan Hurley's Huskies accomplish the rare feat despite likely facing No. 1 seed Florida in the Round of 32?

Below, I'll do my best to help you prepare, forecasting my Sweet 16 for this year's big dance.

*Click here to play the NCAA March Madness Men's Bracket Challenge.*

**Predictions for Sweet 16 Matchups**

Auburn vs. UC San Diego

Michigan State vs. Iowa State

Despite losing three of their final four games, Auburn still ended up as the top No. 1 seed in this year's big dance.

The Tigers have won an impressive 16 of 21 Quad 1 games and boast one of the nation's best offenses, led by Wooden Award Finalist Johni Broome.

Their recent struggles shouldn't overshadow how deep this program is, and making it to at least the Sweet 16 is expected—even with a potentially challenging Round of 32 matchup against Louisville or Creighton.

In the Sweet 16, it's quite likely the Tigers will face fourth-seeded Texas A&M or 12-seed UC San Diego, who I expect to upset Michigan in the opening round.

The Tritons have won 15 straight games and rank in the top 35 of the [NET Rankings](https://www.ncaa.com/rankings/basketball-men/d1/ncaa-mens-basketball-net-rankings), an impressive ranking for a mid-major program.

In the bottom of the draw, two-seed Michigan State could face difficulties with the winner of Marquette-New Mexico, but nonetheless should be able to advance given their dominant defense and top-tier record (13-5) in Quad 1 games this season.

In the Sweet 16, it would not be a surprise for the Spartans to face an Iowa State team that, despite being without senior guard Keshon Gilbert, is still exp…

title: NCAA Tournament 2025 bracket: Unbiased simulation predicts surprising upsets, March Madness picks and sleepers
author: CBS Sports Staff •
url: https://www.cbssports.com/general/news/ncaa-tournament-2025-bracket-unbiased-simulation-predicts-surprising-upsets-march-madness-picks-and-sleepers/
hostname: cbssports.com
description: When does the March Madness 2025 schedule start, and when are 2025 NCAA Tournament brackets due? The 2025 March Madness bracket begins on Thursday, March 20
sitename: CBSSports.com
date: 2025-03-20
---
The UC San Diego Tritons made the 2025 NCAA bracket in their first year eligible for the NCAA Tournament after transitioning from Division II. They went 30-4, winning both the Big West's regular season and conference tournament titles and enter the Big Dance as a No. 12 seed in the South Region. The Tritons rank 35th in the NCAA's NET Ranking metric, among the top non-power conference schools. Led by star guard Aniwaniwa Tait-Jones (19.5 points per game), UCSD will face off against Big Ten Tournament champion Michigan in the Round of 64 of March Madness 2025. Can the No. 12 Tritons pull the upset over the No. 5 seed Wolverines? Before you make your 2025 NCAA Tournament predictions, [see the March Madness bracket picks from the proven computer model at SportsLine](https://www.sportsline.com/insiders/2025-sportsline-upset-bracket-full-of-surprises/#ttag=03162025_agg_cbssports_picks_basketball_ncaa_model_MMupsetbracket1).

Last year, SportsLine's computer simulation nailed massive upsets, including huge wins by No. 11 Oregon over No. 6 South Carolina, No. 11 NC State over No. 6 Texas Tech, No. 10 Colorado over No. 7 Florida, and No. 12 James Madison over No. 5 Wisconsin last year. The model has beaten over 91 percent of all CBS Sports bracket players in four of the past six tournaments.

This model, which simulates every game 10,000 times, has nailed 24 first-round upsets by double-digit seeds since its inception in 2016 and nailed UConn's championship run last year. It nailed 13 teams in the Sweet 16 and was all over Alabama's Cinderella run to the Final Four as a 4-seed.

Now, SportsLine's advanced computer model has simulated the entire 2025 March Madness bracket 10,000 times to come up with the perfect 2025 NCAA Tournament bracket and find out which teams will pull off the biggest upsets. You shouldn't even think about making a pick [without seeing what their model has to say](https://www.sportsline.com/insiders/2025-sports…

Based on the gathered evidence, here is the analysis regarding the probability of an Ivy League team making it to the Sweet Sixteen of the 2025 NCAA men's tournament:

1. **Yale's Performance and Potential Upset**: Yale won the Ivy League tournament and secured a berth in the NCAA tournament. They are predicted by the SportsLine model to potentially upset No. 4 Texas A&M in the first round. Yale has only lost once in 2025 and is led by a strong player, John Poulakidas, who averaged 19.2 points per game.

2. **Competitive Landscape**: Despite Yale's strong performance, the overall competitive landscape of the tournament is challenging. The Bleacher Report predictions did not mention any Ivy League teams in the Sweet Sixteen, focusing instead on stronger teams like Auburn, Michigan State, and UConn.

3. **Historical Context**: Historically, Ivy League teams have been underdogs in the NCAA tournament. While upsets are possible, they are not common for Ivy League teams to advance to the Sweet Sixteen.

4. **Predictions and Simulations**: The CBS Sports simulation predicts a potential upset by Yale in the first round, but there is no strong indication that they will advance to the Sweet Sixteen. The model's track record of predicting upsets gives some hope, but it remains a difficult path.

Considering these factors, while there is a possibility for an Ivy League team like Yale to make a surprising run, the probability remains low given the competition and historical performance.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.15
